misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting in ascending order and then accessing the last element will give the highest score. However, they implemented bubble sort with the condition `if (leftScore > rightScore)`, which sorts in ascending order (smallest to largest). After sorting in ascending order, the last element contains the minimum value, not the maximum.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student conflates 'ascending order sort' with 'getting the highest value.' In ascending order, the smallest value ends up last after a left-to-right pass. The student appears to assume that after sorting 'in ascending order' the highest value will be at index N-1, but actually it will be at index 0. The swap condition `leftScore > rightScore` performs ascending order sorting, yet the code then retrieves `names[lastIndex]` where `lastIndex = N - 1`, expecting the maximum there.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The program outputs the student with the lowest score instead of the highest score. For the sample input (scores: 85, 92, 78), the output will be 'Top student: Charlie (78)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)'.
